name: Mia Mahmoud
comment info:
These two different graphs show the transformation of retail jobs and department stores from 2002 to 2016. However, graph A reveals the net change of the jobs and stores, while graph B depicts the percentage change. The scales (y-axis) of the graphs are quite different, thus a clear comparison with distinct numbers will be unlikely.
The two graphs show a decrease of department stores; however, the rates of the decrease are significantly different. In graph A, the decrease is over 500 in some areas; while the graph B shows a general decrease a general of less than 100. Graph A shows a gradually increase of e- commerce, while graph B shows a faster one within the time frame. The large scale of graph A makes it very hard to decide how much the e- commerce has risen, while graph B shows a 300 increase.
There is a rise in the total retail industry on both graphs, but there is a very slight increase seen on graph B. The increase of the total industry of graph A was seen with a rise over 500,000. The same idea is presented in the rise of warehouse clubs and others.
These results are in response of new technology that allows one to buy ideas online much easier. I also believe that there is a need for jobs to be filled in existing department stores, before new one are built.

Both graphs illustrate the same general information, but Graph A depicts it via net change, using money by the thousands, which Graph B illustrates the percent change. The story that these graphs are telling points to the increasingly shifting tides of retail as it orients away from department stores and more towards e-commerce. If the second graph is any indication, the retail industry isn't changing; it's the scope of it and the means of it that are changing its very definition. name: Ava Voelker
comment info:
Looking at both the net and percentage change in retail jobs in the past 15 years, the most prominent feature is the positive slopes of E-commerce and Warehouse clubs/other jobs. It is clear that these positions are much more popular today than they were in 2002. I also notice the declining slope of department store jobs, indicating their decrease in popularity. Overall, the total retail industry has seen an increase since 2002, but has experienced intermittent decline (for example, in 2008 we see the slope plummet exponentially, likely due to the stock market crash of 2008). 

I can infer that the increasing number of retail positions in Ecommerce and Warehouse clubs is because of their increased utilization and popularity. Both online and in large stores, wide varieties of merchandise are available, easily accessible, and much cheaper than in department stores, making them the sought after option. Because online shopping and warehouse stores receive many customers and transactions, they require larger staffs to satisfy the needs of the store. The more successful they are, the more chains can be opened, hence increasing the workforce even further.  The recent unpopularity of department stores is likely due to people turning to these cheaper alternatives; hence, the more ecommerce and warehouse clubs dominate the retail industry, the more department store shopping will decline. Less traffic in department stores requires less staffing, and therefore, fewer jobs.

name: Moderator Paul
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded during this very busy time before vacation.  Did the graph make you want to shop for presents?

Many noticed that Graph A is the net change in jobs and Graph B is the percentage change.  Could you see how the net change was reflected in the percentage?  I think we were not surprised by the large increase in e-commerce jobs and corresponding large decrease in department store jobs.  But, we wondered whether this has affected sales.   And many wondered about the Warehouse graph. How did that coincide with the e-commerce jobs? Is there a connection between the two? Do we buy more or less with e-commerce?  What’s the future for retail jobs and sales? So many questions to consider.

Since we continue to post responses, whenever they arrive, is there more that you notice?  More that you wonder?  Talk to your classmates and even read the moderators’ responses.  Maybe something they say will lead to more things you notice, wonder, and conjecture.     

Remember to check back on Friday, December 15 to learn more about these graphs -- and we hope to see you again next month on Tuesday, January 9 (always the second Tuesday of the month) for our next "What's Going On In This Graph?"   Signing off now -- Sharon in Boston and Paul in Washington, DC.  See you next year!

comment info: Hey there everyone! We put a challenge to you this month by giving you twice the fun - two graphs for the price of one!  Have you noticed any similarities between the two? Differences?  How are they related? Do they make sense in conjunction with each other?  There's a lot going on here - see what you can discover - just in time for the holiday season!

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info: Welcome to Raleigh, NC and Madison, GA students.  You are so right – something is afloat in retail.  As Maggie Hall says, “The traditional approach of demonstrate-and-persuade is not applicable when you can’t talk to customers face to face.”  You noted increases and decreases in jobs, but check out the titles of the graphs.  How do the graphs relate to each other?  Keep digging.

name: Lipi Desai
comment info:
I notice on Graph A that the x-axis is going by two years in which the Total Retail Industry experienced the most amount of variability going from 2002, going from the negative numbers to above the +500,000 mark. However, the Warehouse Clubs and E-commerce increased, but the Warehouse clubs had the most increasing net change. In Graph B, I noticed that the graph is now in percentage change, which made it seem like E-commerce had the largest increase, while the Warehouse had significantly less.
     I wonder how the Warehouse club has the most significant increase because we are in the age of technology and innovation. I wonder what the Total Retail Industry did to increase their net change over the course of 2002 to 2016.
     The story that the graph represents is the increase and decline of many shopping markets throughout the course of 14 years

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Great observations Lipi. What do you think might be driving the Warehouse numbers? That might be a good thing to research.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to What’s Going On in This Graph?.  It’s December and many of us are buying gifts for the holidays.  Are you buying in stores or are you buying online – e-commerce?  These graphs tell a story about how our buying habits are changing.   

What do you NOTICE? What may this imply?

What do you WONDER? Where could you find the answers to what you wonder?

What’s GOING ON in these graphs?  What can you infer that is beyond what the graphs show directly?

The questions are intended to build on one another, so try to answer them in order.  Start with “I notice” and then “I wonder,” and end with “The story this graph tells is ….”

This month, we have two graphs.  Think about relating the graphs to each other to gain more insights.

Wouldn’t you love to hear what other students have to say about your response?  Read some responses.  Then, press "Reply" to an interesting response to get a discussion going.

We look forward to reading your discoveries.

name: Ramon Zamudio
comment info: The increase in warehouse clubs are due to many reasons, including the increase in demand of more items, faster. This is only one of the many reasons this industry has been increasing over the past 15 years. This more items, faster view also is a result of the high percentage change in retail jobs over the last 15 years. Why drive somewhere to a store that might have your item, when you can shop for it and buy it from the comfort of your home?

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Ramon - great observation about not having to drive somewhere. With regards to the Warehouses, when you comment on the "increase in demand of more items, faster." - could you elaborate on that?

name: Maggie Hall
comment info: This graph clearly showcases the growth in e-commerce over the years. As people move towards preferring online shopping, the job of sales executives has changed form. Commissions are now made in innovative advertising and recommendations, luring people deeper into the online shopping maze. The traditional approach of demonstrate-and-persuade is not applicable  when you can’t talk to customers face to face.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: Maggie what an awesome answer! It sounds like you are in the business! Where do you see the warehouse data fitting in with this? What connections can you make between the two graphs?

name: Grace Alexander
comment info: I noticed that in both Graph A and Graph B, department stores are decreasing while E-commerce and Warehouse clubs both increase. name: Valeria Notte
comment info: This graph is representing the decrease in employment in department stores, and retail stores, and the increase in e-shopping store. This is probably due to the rise of stores such as Amazon, E-Bay, and Craigslist. As more and more people are finding the comfort in shopping at home, less people are going to the mall and buying products. This graph represents the constant, growing incline in online shopping, and the decline in retail jobs.

name: Hanna
comment info: These graphs shows the correlation of sales in different department sellers over time, showing the decline in department store net sales compared to the exponential growth in e-commerce (ex amazon) in recent years.

name: Thomas Fulcher
comment info: I've noticed in graph A that Warehouse clubs and other has had the greatest increase compared to the other retail jobs. Total retail industry has dips and rises, but it does, overall, have a positive net change. E-commerce started out small and slowly grew. E-commerce never dipped below 0, but it didn't have large growth. Department stores, however, has dipped below 0, and it has never came back up. I believe that department stores are going "out of fashion" as the line for department stores is sinking. In graph B, another image is being captured. In Graph A, warehouse clubs and other trumped all other retail jobs. However, in Graph B, E-commerce easily beats out all other retail jobs, which I expected all along. Warehouse clubs and other still rises steadily. Total retail industry barely rises above 0. Department stores stays below 0, just as I expected again. Overall, the only change between the two graphs is that E-commerce has a higher percentage change than Warehouse clubs and other.

name: Srisatya Pusuluri
comment info:
I notice on Graph A that Warehouse clubs and other had the most net change retail jobs over the last 15 years. The reasons are endless for the big net change. Also, the retail industry has the second net change in retail jobs over the last 15 years. This may be because of the rise of the industry this time of year. I notice on Graph B that E-commerce has the most percentage change in retail jobs over the last 15 years this may be because jobs are needed in their warehouses and other shifts in the company.
I wonder why the e-commerce has the least positive change over the last 15 years. I would expect that it would be the most because of the rise of Amazon, and many other e-commerce companies. I also wonder why the total retail industry is rising. Maybe as the population of the world increases, the need for clothes increasing. Maybe in the near future the retail industry will move to e-commerce but, I believe that trying and buying clothes will still be something to watch for in the future.
The story these graphs are telling us is the decline of regular department and the rise of e-commerce and online shopping, shown in both Graph A and B. Jobs that used to be in Department stores have shifted to e-commerce. This graph was justified by Black Friday where online shopping sharply rose.  This is what's going on in this graph.
